episode.title: Buckley v. American Constitutional Law Foundation Inc.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Number 97-930, Victoria Buckley v. The American Constitutional Law Foundation.
General Norton.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Colorado views the initiative process as an essential part of our law making function.
The right of initiative is the first section under the Colorado constitution under the heading, Legislative Department.

Because this is an important process to State government we have established a limited structure of regulation intended to safeguard the people's right to democratic self government while ensuring the fairness of our election process.
Beyond the two viewpoints represented in the courtroom today, there are two other important interests that are protected through our regulatory process.
The first is the interest of those who may oppose an initiative, and the second is the interest of the signers of the petition.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: May I ask just one factual question?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I understand there's a final reporting requirement, a disclosure requirement, and that is not challenged here.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: That is correct.
It is the reports that deal with the monthly reporting requirement as to the individual petition circulators.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, does the financial disclosure that's made at the end, and it's not challenged, separate out the amount that's paid for solicitors, so if I read the report I know that they spent X dollars for TV advertising and Y dollars for... to pay circulators?
Do I... can I find that out from the final report?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: The final report would list all of the expenditures included among the expenditures of the sponsoring campaign committee--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: What I'm asking, is it a lump sum, or is it separated out?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --It is separated out in detail.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And when is that final report due?
Is that before the election or after?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: I'm not sure, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It would also show the amounts that went to the individual petition circulators?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --that may be filed with the petition when the petition is completed?
Isn't that when that report gets filed?
I thought the monthly reports were while the petition was in circulation.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: The monthly reports are while it is in circulation.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But when the completed petition is there, and the sponsor says, we have enough votes, at that time the so called final report would go in?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Your Honor, I'm not sure what the due date is for the final report.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is there anything in the monthly disclosure statements that break it down expenditure by expenditure, so if I looked at the monthly disclosure statement, could I see how much was paid just for circulating?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: The monthly disclosure statement lists the amounts that are paid to each individual circulator on a person by person basis.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That was struck down.
Has anything in the monthly disclosure statement been allowed to stand--

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: The--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --by the district court's opinion?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --What has been struck down is simply the amount that applies to individual circulators.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: All right.
In that monthly disclosure statement, so far as the statute has been allowed to stand--

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --can I see how much is paid, lump sum, for circulation?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: You would have to add up the amount that is paid to each individual circulator.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, except that's been struck down.
Okay.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Signature gathering serves the same function as a primary election in a candidate selection process.
By obtaining the requisite 54,242 signatures, an initiative's backers establish that it has a significant modicum of support.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, there's this difference between signature gathering and a primary election.
In a primary election it is not somebody trying to persuade somebody else.
Signature gathering may perform that function, but it is, in addition, and perhaps primarily, one citizen trying to persuade another citizen about the merits of a particular legislature proposal.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Here, there are three functions that all occur simultaneously.
That is the aspect of persuasiveness, as you have described.

There is also a role that the circulator plays of an administrative function akin to an election judge, and there is also the function of acting as an agent or fiduciary for the signer in fulfilling responsibilities as to the signer.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, do... is there any way of telling from this record whether the typical petitioner circulator goes door to door, or sits in a shopping mall?
I suppose they do both.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: They may do both.
The practice is ordinarily to go to a shopping mall or some place where there are many people gathered.
The--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And so--

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --record does not specifically describe that in the trial court.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --What is the interest of the State that you say supports the requirement that the circulators have to be registered voters?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: That is two part.
First of all, is because they are fulfilling a law making function, we as a State should be able to say that those who are fulfilling that function should be people who are committed to--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: In light of Meyer, I would have thought the State would have a hard time asserting that its interest in having them be registered voters can prevail.
No doubt there are people in the State who are not registered voters, but who nonetheless would like to serve as petition circulators and debate the merits of given issues.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --We are happy to have people debate the merits and to enter into a persuasive function.
It is only when they perform the administrative election judge type functions of ensuring that those who are signing the petition are who they say they are, that a husband is not signing for a wife--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --Well, why can't somebody who is a resident of Colorado, who's an adult resident, perform that function just as well as somebody who's a registered voter?
I just don't understand.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --The registration requirement is different from a residency requirement in that it requires a person to swear an oath that they are a resident of the State before they begin the circulating process.
There is a requirement that they do so at the end of the circulating process as part of the affidavit if registration and residency are separated.
But here, we have an assurance all the way through the process that they're going to be here.
It ties in with the second justification for that, and that is in preventing fraud.
We have had the problem of people who come to the State simply to circulate petitions.
If those people are not going to be around several months later when we actually go through the process of having an administrative hearing to--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes, but you require an affidavit at the end of the day, when the petition is filed, that the circulator is, in fact, a resident.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --That is ordinarily our process--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And you have the normal criminal laws that could enforce that, so it's very difficult for me to understand, in the face of Meyer, what State justification you can offer for also requiring that the circulator be a registered voter.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --This would ensure that they are a resident throughout the entire time that they are circulating the petition, rather than just at the moment they submit--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Why isn't that--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Isn't there something in the record that suggests that it's easier to determine whether someone is a registered voter than it is to determine whether they're a resident?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --We have specific lists of registered voters.
We do not have lists of people who are otherwise residents.
It gives us a concrete place to answer that question.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Is it any part of your rationale on the registered voters that if you don't want to count yourself in the political community by not voting, you shouldn't take part in this, or is it simply a kind of way of verifying that the person is, indeed, a resident?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: It is a way of verifying that a person is, indeed, a resident, and that is correct, but it is also... there's also two parts.

To the extent that someone is playing a formal role in the process, which they are doing, we would require that they be registered voters in a way as part of being committed to the Colorado law making process, just as we require our legislators to be committed, just as we require election judges and those who participate in nominating conventions to be registered voters.
If they want to participate in the purely advocacy function, to stand next to someone who is a registered voter, they are perfectly free to do that and to act as advocates.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: How do you get around the fact that, despite the complexity of function, and I will concede to you that they are performing functions in the electoral process, how do you get around the fact that Meyer says they're also engaging in core speech, and if they're engaging in core speech, they're going to be... your restrictions are going to be judged on a very restrictive standard.
How do you get around Meyer in that respect?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: We believe that, even under a strict scrutiny analysis, that our laws would satisfy that strict scrutiny.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why is that?
Let's talk about... why is it easier to prevent fraud somehow when you're dealing with a resident than with a nonresident?
You think Coloradans are more honest than non Coloradans?
[Laughter]
Is that the rationale?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Well, we would like to think so.
Our rationale is being able to find people.
If someone is a registered voter, they have taken an oath saying that they are a resident.
That gives us some assurance that they may be around when questions arise.
Someone may seek a signature.
It may be 6 months later, at the time an administrative hearing is held to inquire into questions abut the validity of that signature, and if those people have left the State, we cannot subpoena--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, do you think registered voters are more apt to leave the State than people who haven't registered?
I mean, are less apt to leave the State than people who haven't registered?
Is there any statistic to show which ones, which segment of the population is more mobile than the other?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --To the extent that we are dealing with the problem of... that is described in the amicus briefs of the State and Local Legal Center and of the States, we are seeing the development of bands of people who go from State to State simply to circulate petitions, and--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And don't they have to provide you with their... you could require them to provide you with their name and address so that even though they're itinerant you can still... you know, you can find who they were.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --We may know that they live in California, but we cannot subpoena them in California and we cannot prosecute them for having engaged in fraud.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Have you ever prosecuted any petition gatherer?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Yes, we have.
In the record it shows the 1992 cycle, in which we successfully prosecuted three people for forgery.
We attempted to prosecute three others, but were not able to serve the warrant because they had left the State.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Were these gatherers or signers?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: These were gatherers.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I'll grant you it would be easier if you didn't have to go to California, but I mean, if the fraud is serious you can start an extradition proceeding, can't you?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: We were not able to, as a practical matter, do that in this situation.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, why, because it cost too much money?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: It would have... we had a problem with our... because it is a misdemeanor in some situations, we would not be able to do that.
In other situations it was trying to serve warrants.
We were not able to do that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But the only justification for the registration requirement you've given us is that it's easier to find their address if they're registered.
Right?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: No.
It's twofold.
It's also our interest as a State in having people who participate in our law making process be citizens and registered voters.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, you can require that they be residents without requiring that they be registered voters.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: We could have a process that would require them to swear an oath saying that they--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I'm a resident, and this is my address.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --residence when they begin the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --initiative process--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --and then when they end.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But you also--

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: It's a question of timing.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --You also said, I think, it was much easier for the State to determine whether someone was actually a registered voter or not than to determine whether they're actually a resident.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: How many of these people are we talking about?
How much of a burden is that on the State that you save by simply going to the registration book?
Does the State do that, go to the registration rolls and check that all these people are actually registered?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Yes, we do, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And how many people are you talking... how many of these election gypsies are there who wander around from State to State?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: There can be several hundreds in any--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Several hundreds?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --In any given petition there may be several hundred circulators.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's not a whole lot of people.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: May I ask on candidate petitions, petitions circulated in order to enable someone to run as a candidate in an election, they also use petition circulators.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Does Colorado law require that those circulators be registered voters?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Yes, it does.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So presumably the same argument made here today with regard to the petition circulation would apply to candidate petitions as well--

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --if the respondents are correct.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Suppose that it were shown that in most cases in Colorado initiatives were circulated by paid solicitors who didn't really care which side they were on, they were just doing it to get the pay, they'd circulate a petition on either side of any issue.
Suppose that were the fact most of the time.
Would that undermine the rationale of our recent opinion in Meyers?
It was unanimous opinion.
It was recent.
I doubt that we would want to revisit it.
I noticed in your brief that you seem to be questioning the rationale that core speech does take place at the in it... at the signature gathering stage.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: The Burdick approach that we would urge the Court to adopt recognizes that there is both core speech aspect, where there would be a severe burden on that speech, potentially, and the ability of the States to have a regulatory process.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Burdick was in the context of a primary election, with rules about parties and so forth, and the assumption of Meyers was that a core speech function, a very viable speech function in the initiative process takes place at the signature gathering stage, so that it's not analogous to the candidate qualifying thing, and I'm asking if you think that distinction holds.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Meyer, I believe, did not adequately recognize the other aspects of the process.
It focused on the core speech part, which was truly at issue in Meyer, and did not look at the other issues of the State in--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Are you saying that core speech does not take place routinely in the signature gathering process, and you're denying that as an empirical matter that the Court is factually wrong?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --No.
Core speech--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, you can say we're wrong if you think we're wrong.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --In terms of advocacy, that is one part of it, but there are several transactions taking place simultaneously.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How much do we actually know about this, or how much did we know about it in Meyer?

You know, if, in fact, someone sits at a shopping center and waits for people to come up to them, and they're anxious to get as many signatures as they can, one would suspect that there's not much debate.
If someone is going to say, I don't like that proposition, the petition circulator just says, okay, go on.
I want someone who will sign.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: We believe the State and Local Government Center in its brief has presented a fairly accurate view of what the transaction ordinarily looks like.
It is an attempt to get as many people through to just sign, rather than going through an extensive process of explaining the petition.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Why does the State insist that the circulator have to have the circulator's name on a badge, as opposed to just saying, volunteer, or paid circulator?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: That is to address the problem that we have of trying to maintain the integrity of the process as it is going along.

If the Secretary of State's office receives a phone call that says, I saw a petition circulator paying people to sign petitions, which is clearly a violation of State law, we get a call that says, it was a man with brown hair standing at the corner of Sixth and Broadway, at that point in time, we don't have any petitions.
We can't look at the signature on that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Has this been a problem?
Has this--

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Yes, it has, and that is reflected in the record.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --How often, of paying people to sign petitions?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: That is... that has been a problem that has been prosecuted.
That is an example--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: How often?
How many prosecutions have there been of this sort?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --There have not been recent prosecutions on that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Have there been any prosecutions, recent or otherwise?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: I believe that there are some earlier cases on that.
I've not seen any in the last--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: General Norton, if you have the petition with the person's name on it, and you have a badge that says, paid solicitor, and the sponsor's name, just not that person's name, then the burden that you have been informing us of is substantially reduced, is it not?
I mean, you know from the petition who were the signers of that particular petition.
The person is required to identify the sponsor, and that that person is paid or volunteer.
Why isn't that adequate?
Why do you need the name in addition?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --We've had an example that is reflected in the record where the opponent saw a petition circulator misrepresenting the contents of the petition.
They took pictures of the circulator, but even with those pictures at a subsequent hearing we were not able to identify who those individuals--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But if you knew the sponsor, if the sponsor had to be identified, if you had everything that you now require on the badge, why... and you have the picture, well, the sponsor knows who's been hired, don't they?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --Even under those circumstances it is an individual violation for the circulator to engage in misconduct, and the sponsor may or may not be able to identify who is standing on a particular street corner, or who is in a picture.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Are you this careful in registering voters, as opposed to collecting petitions that would undo the work of the legislature?

You see, I come into this with the attitude that legislatures don't like these things, because they're usually collected in order to do something that the legislature doesn't want it to, or to undo something that the legislature has done.
Now, has your legislature been this concerned about the slightest chance of fraud with respect to, let us say, registering to vote?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: That is something that has been largely dictated by Federal legislation in recent years that has caused us to make our laws less strict.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I see.
But you used to be this careful before the drive through registration laws.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: We used to be more careful than we currently are.
You are correct that we are not able to be as careful in the voter registration process.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: If... I just have one question I'd like to ask, which is that if... I assume... I'll assume for argument's sake that you're right, that there's an aspect in which this petition gatherer is like a voting official who sits in a booth, so the State can regulate, but that petition gatherer is also a person who's likely to try to persuade someone to sign the petition, and to that extent there's speech involved, persuasive political speech, so if I think there's both, what standard do I apply, and which case do you look to to give me the right standard?
In other words, I think there's a lot of speech involved, but I also think it's pretty important that the State can regulate its process for making laws.
Now... so I think both, and so since I think both, what case do I look to?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: I would urge you to look at the Burdick standard.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, Burdick was just a question of write ins, wasn't it?
That was pure process, or pretty pure process, so I'm still looking.
I've looked in the labor area, like picketing, I've looked in... there's... but I want your opinion.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: I believe that the Burdick standard would allow you to take into account both the pure speech aspects of it, when you look--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: The Burdick standard being--

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --Having a flexible standard such that a severe burden on speech would cause a strict scrutiny standard to be applied.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --What about Buckley, too?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Buckley.
Have you looked at Buckley?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Yes.
Buckley--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
So what... now, thinking of both those cases, what standard would you articulate that we should use?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --Buckley is a strict scrutiny case, as is Meyer v. Grant.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I thought you would say Meyer v. Grant immediately, because that also involves exactly the same two things that are involved here.
It involved the persuasive function and the--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --If I thought--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --what we call the administrative function.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: If I thought that Meyer was not dealing with the aspect in which the petition gatherer is an arm of the State's electoral process, which the State could regulate from that point of view, just as it could somebody in an election booth... you know, the person who sits there... but both are involved, what standard should I use?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: I would urge the Burdick standard as allowing the examination of both of those aspects.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Why not the Timmons, which is the more recent precedent?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Timmons, in my mind, applies the same standard.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: For you to win do you have... do we have to somehow modify Meyer?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Meyer--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Or clarify it, or restrict it, for you to win on all these points?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --I believe that if strict scrutiny is applied we win on all of our points nevertheless.

However, I think for... from the State perspective, for our ability to regulate our process and understand what the rules are going to be, it would be better for us, it would make more sense to apply the Burdick and to--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, General Norton, Justice O'Connor asked you a question.
She said, if you are to prevail here, do we have to modify or clarify Meyer, and you refer to Burdick.
What's your answer to her question?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --No, because I believe that under strict scrutiny we can prevail under the Meyer standard as well.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Despite the fact that the voter registration requirement and the disclosure of the name seem to fly squarely in the face of what the Court said in Meyer.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Strict scrutiny was the standard applied in Buckley v. Valeo, as well as in other cases that have upheld regulation of the electoral--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I don't think strict scrutiny was applied across the board in Buckley, General Norton.
I mean, there were several different kinds of requirements there, and I would... perhaps you've read it more recently than we have.
I would not have said that strict scrutiny was applied across the board.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --I believe that that was the standard that was applied to the disclosure requirements and the other aspects that are parallel to this particular case.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Let me put the... Justice O'Connor's question slightly differently.
If you cannot prevail under strict scrutiny, then you cannot prevail unless we modify Meyer.
Isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: If I thought that this case turned on whether or not there really was meaningful speech at the signature gathering process, if I thought that was determinative, where would I go to find that out?
Have there been things written about it, or--

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: There are... there are some--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --this record is very sparse on all of these points.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --The briefs have been filed by the amici, including the National Voter Outreach Organization, which employs petition circulators.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Excuse me.
What do you mean by meaningful speech?
Could you define this term?
If I come up to you and say, vote for Smith, or I have a sign that says, vote for Smith, is that meaningful speech, or do I have to tell you why?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: I would say, vote for Smith is meaningful speech--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Core political speech, isn't it?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --Sign this petition is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Would you sign this petition?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --Sign this petition is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is not--

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --asking people to fulfill an elective function.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Sign this petition to lower taxes, meaningful speech again?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Meaningful speech with a combination of the electoral function.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But isn't that passed in Meyer?

I mean, the question there was, could you have paid solicitors for initiatives, and the Court said that the job that's being done, asking people to sign the thing, involves core speech, so I think in light of Justice Kennedy's question that the answer's got to be yes.
If you're going to say that no, this really isn't core speech, then you have to qualify Meyer, that said it is.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Then the State is left with no way to ensure that those 54,000 signatures are collected--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But wasn't there first a good part of this that the Tenth Circuit upheld?
I mean, they didn't just strike down this thing wholesale, and at least as I read it, it comes... it permits the identification of the sponsor, the statement whether a person is paid or volunteer.

What it doesn't permit is the name, insistence that the name go on the badge, and that the amount spent not only in gross for all petition solicitors but person by person, but that's... but that's really what's at stake, the name, and do you have to not only tell how much you spent on solicitors altogether, but how much you paid each individual?
As I understand it, that's all that's at stake.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --That's... that is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And identification as a paid solicitor?
Wasn't that stricken out?
Do they have to identify themselves as paid solicitors?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --The requirement that by badge they identify themselves as paid solicitors was stricken by the Tenth Circuit.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It was also--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Yes, but as far as I understand, they were doing that in connection with a name as well.
Do we know from this case whether, if all that the law required was, paid by X sponsor, that that... that the Tenth Circuit would have found anything wrong with that?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: But the Tenth Circuit did not differentiate.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well, General Norton.
Mr. O'Toole.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

What the respondents ask this Court to do is to fortify and reinforce the message that was given in Meyer to assure that the activity of citizens peaceably gathering together to change Government under a constitutional system such as we have in the State of Colorado is furthered by the First Amendment.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You think it takes fortification?
We couldn't just apply Meyer.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You think if we just applied Meyer, you lose?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --The reason we ask you... Your Honor, I would say to you that unfortunately reviewing decisions from other circuits it appears that there's some question about what this Court meant in Meyer.
I think it's clear.
I don't think there's any doubt.
I think the test that's laid out in Meyer, that talks about the burden being well nigh insurmountable, couldn't be clearer.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, Meyer was different factually in a way.

I think you can look at Meyer as an offspring, kind of, of the Buckley case, that just as you can't tell someone they can't spend their own money to finance their campaign, you can't tell someone that they can't hire petitioners to... hire circulators to go around and circulate something.
But this goes beyond whether or not you can hire petitioners or not, or circulators.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, I beg to differ with you on that issue.
I think--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You think the facts of this case are the same as Meyer?
That's... I'm telling you the facts are different.
Now, you disagree?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I'm talking about the facts.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --I'd say that the facts because of facts differ, that evidence that was presented in this case was not necessarily the same evidence presented in Meyer.
The facts described in response to Justice Kennedy are very close.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But Meyer was... as I recall was paid circulators, and here we're talking about different requirements.
We're not talking about--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: I understand.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --really a prohibition against paid circulators.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Excuse me, Mr. Chief Justice.
We're not dealing with prohibition against paid circulators.
We are dealing with prohibition against the circulation of petitions by residents or nonresidents who do not deign, for one reason or another, to become a registered voter.
We're dealing with their ability to be engaged in the same--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I didn't think we were dealing with residents versus nonresidents.
I thought we were dealing with a requirement that the circulator be a registered voter in Colorado.
Is that what we're dealing with?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Yes--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Yes, Justice O'Connor.
We're dealing with that issue.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Now, at the same time, I guess Colorado, like other States, requires a certain number of signatures from registered voters.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: A certain percentage, in order to gain access to the ballot for a petition.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: That is correct.
It's 5 per--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Now, under your theory, I guess, that also inhibits speech, because it deters the filing of these initiative petitions.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Your Honor--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What if Colorado tried to increase the number of signatures required?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Your Honor, in terms of how I'm addressing this issue with regard to registered circulators who are aggrieved in the speech process, I do believe there might be a different analysis that would attend whether or not or how the State assures that it has a modicum of public support for the measure so it's on the ballot.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, does strict scrutiny apply to that requirement, in your view?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: In my opinion, yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mm hmm.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Because I believe that--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So that's the next step we'll face.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --It's possible.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why do you say--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --haven't even paid for that yet or volunteered yet, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Why do you insist on making your case harder?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Because I'm asked the questions.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It seems to me it's quite a different issue how many votes you need to get.
That doesn't involve core political speech.
We're talking about persuading people to sign, as opposed to how many people need to sign, and you think the two questions have to be equated.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Oh, I... no, Your Honor, I don't.
I was asked a question by the... by Justice O'Connor, and I felt, in light of the Court's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That is very different.
I would think one goes to the procedure involved in making this change, and the other goes to the question of one citizen trying to get another one to sign up or to support a particular proposition.
You don't see a fundamental difference between those two?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --I was asked that question.
I'm giving you an answer.
My answer is no, but for purposes of this case, that other issue is not before us.
We are dealing with core political speech, Justice Scalia, and I believe that the process is adequately delineated in footnote 4 of the Meyer decision.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But let me ask you--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --What about the requirement in most States that there's certain qualifications for circulating nominating petitions.
There's the person who goes door to door, and you have to have so many signatures to get on the ballot.
Now, is that circulator engaging in core political speech, in your view?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Not to the same extent, because he's proceeding with... I think this Court has consistently drawn a distinction between ballot initiative, where there's a discussion of issues and a discussion of candidates.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: But of course they are engaging--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --You know... so the person in the shopping center collecting signatures says, vote for this anti tax referendum.
The person coming to the door with a signature sheet for nominations says, will you sign this nominating petition for Joe Blow?
Those are pretty much the same, aren't they?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Well, the State's interest differs, because under the State... in the State of Colorado, Chief Justice, we have a situation where the people reserve to themselves the right to petition or circulate a citizen's initiative and, in fact, the State's involvement does not occur until that petition itself is submitted to the Secretary of State for approval of the measure in terms of being placed on the ballot.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But I thought people reserved to themselves the right to decide what candidates will get enough signatures to have their names go on the ballot.
They reserve that to themselves.
Why isn't that core political speech?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: The cases on candidacy in my review of them, and it may not have been as scholarly a review as might be required under the circumstances, but I will say to you that this discussion is not over a crowded ballot.
This is not over a question of who can be on the ballot... this candidacy is not a right... but is over the actions of people who gather--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, let's analyze the thing without necess... without any--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Certainly.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --more on a factual basis.

What is the difference factually in terms of core political speech between a person who comes to the door with a nominating petition and says, will you please sign this nominating commission for Joe Blow... petition, and the person who sits in the shopping center and says, will you please sign this referendum for antitax?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Because the State... Chief Justice, the State's interest in curtailing debate and consideration and discussion is significantly less in the former than in the latter.
In the citizen's petition we have a system which guarantees discussion and debate.
We have a core discussion of a political issue.
The State has no power to determine what issues--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. O'Toole, may I ask you a factual question about a--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Yes, Justice.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Colorado law?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Yes, Justice.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The provision being challenged here, such as a requirement to wear a badge--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --do they apply to candidate solicitation?
I mean, solicitation of signatures for a candidate, and to get a candidate's name on the ballot?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: As a factual question it may, but it doesn't.
The--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What do you mean, it may but it doesn't?
Either it does or it doesn't.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --No, I'm sorry, you said it may.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, no, no.
I said, as a matter--
I'm asking you what the Colorado law is.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: In fact, it does not apply to recall or candidate petition, the badge requirement, or the paid circulator badge requirement, or the paid circulator reporting requirements do not apply to either the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So the issue--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --candidate's petition or the recall petition.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --So if we uphold this... the judgment that we're reviewing, that will have no impact one way or another on any existing Colorado law applying to the solicitation of names to put a candidate's name on the ballot.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Could I ask--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --It's hard to see that there's a compelling State interest in having this information if the State doesn't require it for these other matters, isn't it?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: I... we fail to see a compelling State interest in--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But is it possible--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --in... sorry.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --that... the compelling State interest--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Excuse me.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --I take it that's being advanced is that they're afraid that petition gatherers who are paid will say to people in shopping centers, I'll give you a dollar if you sign the petition.
I'll give you 50 cents if you sign the petition.
That's at least what they're saying, and it's not implausible.

Now, if that's a legitimate interest, and it sounds like one, but I agree with you that this is unconstitutional, would I also have to hold unconstitutional an effort by a State to say, we want disclosed how much money you give to a candidate?

In other words, I'm quite concerned about deciding for you in this case and then finding the campaign finance issue before me in another case and suddenly, lo and behold, I've decided that issue here.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: The answer is no, Justice.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: And the reason is that the State interest in avoiding the possibility or view of corruption simply isn't present in a balloting issue.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. O'Toole--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --No, I said what their issue... what their justification is, is that we're afraid that Arco or some big company, and maybe it's not true in Colorado, but it's certainly true in California, that very often large companies want measures on the ballot, and they'll pay people to gather signatures.

And what they're worried about, I take it, in Colorado is a paid petition gatherer will say, I'll pay you 50 cents if you write your name down, which I take it is illegal, and they want a ready method to see if that's happened, and this is their ready method, and that justification's--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Mr. O'Toole, may I just intervene at that point, because they're... we're talking as though there were no measures in California, and I think it ought to be taken out of this case that how much the sponsor paid must indeed be disclosed, and the Tenth Circuit upheld that final report without any ifs, ands, or buts, so the sponsor must tell how much it is paying to get this measure on the ballot.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: That is correct, how much has been expended, Justice Ginsburg.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: In addition, there must be the name of the collector of signatures on each one of these petition collection sheets that he hands the--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: On every individual petition section, the name of the circulator appears.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --And that would be plus the sponsor, so we're not talking about a void of information.
We're talking about Colorado has some information requirement which the Tenth Circuit has upheld.
The question is, isn't Colorado entitled, despite First Amendment concerns, to more than that?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Our answer is no.

We believe that the process that is employed by the State of Colorado is intended to do one thing, and that is to hinder the process of collecting signatures and for individuals to engage in political speech.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, in a sense any regulations may hinder the process.
Probably the least hindering would be no regulation at all, but you don't contend that the State can't regulate it at all.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Chief... Chief Justice, of course they can regulate it, and they do.
They have criminal sanctions for the violation of the act.
They have extensive criminal--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But I'm trying to get this... this is what I'm thinking.
Suppose I think in this case that their justification is trying to catch petition gatherers who will pay for signatures.
Now... and I agree with you, suppose I agree with you that despite that justification this is unconstitutional.
Then, in the next case, someone says, remember that case you just decided?
Now, the State here is requiring various kinds of disclosure of contributions to candidates or other forms of finance disclosure.
At that point you want to say, that's totally different, and I all I want you is to explain why.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --What is sought in Colorado, Justice, is a prophylactic measure to assist the efficiency of the State at the cost of the First Amendment.

Now, efficiency never does take a back seat, and in this particular case the efficiency of identifying these individuals with a badge... and, by the way, this goes to volunteer as well as non, or paid circulators, and certain reporting requirements only go to paid circulators but not to voluntary circulators.
Those requirements essentially chill the process involved in core political speech which is described--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I thought you had no objection to applying to your situation what Justice Breyer is worried about applying to contributors.
You have no objection--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --I have no objection to that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --to disclosing--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --None.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --who the circulators are and that they're paid and how much money is paid, and all of that is, indeed, disclosed, isn't it?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Your Honor, it is disclosed on the petition.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So what Justice Breyer should be asking you is, what if we required contributors to candidates to go around wearing a button that says, contributor to candidate?
That's the parallel, isn't it?

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I know you're going to say yes, and I know what--
[Laughter]
Perhaps what I should be asking.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: I'm glad you know that.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now... maybe what I should be asking, but what I actually am asking, is--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Thank you, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Is why you made that concession?
I'm trying to get in my mind what the reason is that distinguishes between those two things.
I'm looking for the rationale.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Your Honor, in fact, as we tried this case, and as we presented in our complaint, we did not make that concession, and in fact we challenged the affidavit requirement because we believed there were more or less restrictive means in which to gather the ensuring of a modicum of State support was there.
However--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, that I don't understand based on Buckley, because if... let's just make it with a volunteer contributor.
If I am required to disclose how much money I give, why isn't it equally constitutional for me to say I didn't have the money but I gave personal services instead?
Why shouldn't the public know who is contributing to this candidate, and some may contribute money, and some may contribute personal services?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --The public does know, in Colorado, who has contributed to a citizens' initiative.
That is reported.
Contributions are not at stake here.

What we're talking about are reporting requirements for individuals who are engaged in this very specific area of protected speech with their names, their addresses, their business addresses, and they are reported while--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But I thought you just said you objected to the whole thing, including the report--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --that the sponsor has to file, which as I understand it says, I am the sponsor of the initiative, here it is ready to go on the ballot, I spent X amount for paid solicitation.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: In fact, Justice Ginsburg, I apologize if I gave you that impression.
We did oppose the affidavit requirement because we thought it identified individuals too closely with contentious issues.
We did not challenge the expenditure reporting requirements as found under the Campaign Act.
We never challenged that, but we did challenge those parts of the statute which singled out paid circulators, identified them with issues, allowed them to be subjected to potential--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But you're not appealing that here.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So for present purposes--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --why don't you be magnanimous and say, we accept all of that?
You don't even mind having the individual circulators identified in the affidavit that's filed at the end, right?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: At this juncture, it is certainly more than adequate information to allow the State to proceed with any interest they have.
The mention of fraud is a talismanic incantation in these cases, and the long and the short of it is, we don't see it.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Would you--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Yes, Justice--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --think it constitutional to require in bold face type on the front, as a cover sheet for any initiative that a voter signs, the statement, this init... this petition is being circulated by a paid circulator, or an unpaid circulator, as the case may be?
Would you object to that?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Yes, I would, and it would be the same objection that we have to the badge, Justice Kennedy, and the reason I'd object to it is that the protection that's accorded to somebody that's paid in this sacred area of political discussion is the same, and there is no reason... there are three... I think we have... you know, basically this disclosure says that we have the... forces the individual to fear... I mean, or have the risk of fear of Government reprisal--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Now--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --All right.
I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --It seems to me that this promotes free speech rather than retards it.
It gives the voter who's considering signing the petition added information.
Does it--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: It does not promote free speech of the individual seeking to speech... to speak.
It... Justice Kennedy, I believe it may promote some interest in giving more information to the recipient of that speech, which it is our opinion is not the purpose of the First Amendment.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --What's the evil that follows from my hypothetical, because you know what's next, because I'm going to say, well, what's wrong with, say, a badge... forget the badge.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Forget the badge.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Let's say that it's right on the affidavit.
This petition is being circulated by a paid or unpaid volunteer.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: It is our position that that prophylactic... whatever... for whatever... first off, is there a reason for that?
Is the reason--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Oh, the State says this gives information to the voter that the voter would need.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --That's not a compelling State interest that overcomes the right of the individual to participate in anonymous speech.
That's my answer to that.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It's not anonymous.
You don't have to give your name.
All you have to say is whether you're paid or not paid.
You're still anonymous.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: That individual does not have to speak.
It's compelled speech.
That individual is being compelled to speak.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but you allow it on the disclosure report.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Ah.
Well, in the disclosure report what is allowed is a generalized reporting that says expenditures were made to National Voter Outreach.
Now... or whatever paid circulation is taking place.
Remember, we still haven't gotten to the registered circulators in a... by the way, there is no empirical evidence that it turns out that registered voters are less likely to--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Could you--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --commit fraud than--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Could you require a statement on a candidate petition that says at the top, circulated by someone who expects a job--
[Laughter]
--from this candidate if he is elected?
Could you require that statement?
That's very important information for the voter to know.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --It certainly would be--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why not require that?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Could you require that.
I... Your Honor--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That's a tough one.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --You could require that.
If you require that, that's what's going to be done.

But the answer to that I'd say is, to the extent that it creates an impediment to discussion and compels speech, which the speaker has a right to determine and select, it is the nature of his conversation.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Then why do... why can you then... why could you then compel a company to state in the newspaper that it is contributed $1,000 to Joe Jones, who's a candidate, in the form of promising to give him an employment contract as soon as he's finished.
I take it you could compel the latter, or can you?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: I would say--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Then why couldn't you?
How do you reconcile those?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --You're... the part of the speech that you're compelling is not the contribution.
You're compelling the reason.
You're compelling the inherent basis of the conversation--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I suppose another--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --and the political purpose.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --I suppose another answer to my question is, if it's important to the voter, you can ask, are you been paid or not.
If the voter thinks it's important--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: They can ask.
In terms of the process, Justice Kennedy, you asked about that.
I direct your attention to footnote 4 in the Meyer brief.
Also there is adequate... there is discussion in the transcript of the... of how the process works, and it involves going door to door on occasion, but also going to the malls.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Mr. O'Toole, may I ask you another question about the state of the record?

The State... one of the important State interests here is to catch the people who are bribing people to sign petitions, and there's sort of a presumption that paid circulators may do that rather often.
Does the record contain any evidence indicating how... what percentage of paid circulators engage in this kind of conduct and what percentage don't?
I mean, normally we presume people are innocent until they're proved guilty, but here there's kind of a presumption that paid circulators are guilty of this recurring crime.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Justice Stevens--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Does the evidence support that?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Justice Stevens, we argued in the brief we think the evidence--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, I'm not asking what you argued in the brief.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I'm asking you what's in the... what evidence was adduced in the trial court, and what findings, if any, were made?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: The evidence is more indirect than direct.
The evidence substantiates that in 1992 there were 12... 1,200,000 signatures submitted.
The State detected approximately 2,000 of those signatures obtained by fraud.
That's a fifth of a percent, or less than a fifth of a percent.
That is the evidence of fraud, and that is--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Does that indicate how many people were responsible for those fraudulent signatures?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Looked like 15... 9 to 15.
I think they got three convictions.

They did have a... and that's part of the appellee's supplemental appendix, where they had a hearing before the Secretary of State to determine whether certain acts had violated 1-40-130, which is the criminal execution statutes in the petition, and they were not able to find any evidence of fraudulent dissemination of information, and--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But does the evidence show how many of those who did perpetrate fraud were paid and how many were unpaid?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --The only evidence is that 9 to 15 individuals who were paid circulators may have engaged in fraud, 3 of whom got convicted of forgery.
What they actually did, they violated the... they made it a class 4 felony.
They used... they wrote in the identity of individuals.
The Secretary of State, who had the power to check every signature--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: They forged names, I guess--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --That's--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --rather than writing in the identity of individuals.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --They forged names.
I mean, they forged signatures, names, they went through a telephone book.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, then you're saying there was evidence that they had committed fraud.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.
Now, what evidence was there that unpaid solicitors had committed comparable fraud?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: None.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And is there any evidence in any other State... I mean, this occurred in a State which had these requirements which they're trying to defend.
Is there any evidence from States that don't have these requirements--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: There was evidence that in the State of Washington, and that's a higher quantum of signatures needed to show a modicum of support, that there was likewise approximately 1,500 signatures.

It turned out in that particular case factually, and it's part of the amicus brief from the States, that the proponents, who are the first to worry about fraud and being tainted with fraud, found that there had been fraud by circulators, that they had been defrauded, and had therefore turned that in.
There's evidence also in this case that in one such incident the proponent had paid somebody approximately for 6,000 more signatures than they actually got, and they thought they defrauded--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Do these circulators get... they get paid by the name, is that--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --They get paid by the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --So when they forge a name they are cheating not just the State, they're cheating the person who hired them.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Absolutely.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So I assume he would have an interest in preventing their fraud as well.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: And in fact when I... I was involved in the Worker's Choice of Care Amendment.
We set up very stringent guidelines to check every single signature.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Whatever you did, does the State of Colorado have any laws that are aimed at the sponsor, the one who pays, as distinguished from the person who receives the payment?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Well, to the extent that a sponsor involves himself or herself in fraud, they are likewise going to be... could likewise be penalty... penalized--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But there's no kind of respondeat superior liability.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --No.
As far as I... no, there is not a respondeat superior liability.
I'm aware of no instances in which the proponent has been charged and convicted where... in the absence of any overt act on the proponent's part to... or permit the fraud, or encourage the fraud.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: The... what the sponsor must disclose, in addition to the total amount spent on paid petitions, do they... they have to break that down into the per signature amount?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: No, they... no, they don't.

They give a... in the reporting requirement which was not struck down, and which is not before this Court, they give a general reporting of expenditures, the amount, and in this particular instance the amount paid to circulate petitions, there'll be another line item, the amount it cost to buy petitions and have them--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But do you know the number of... I suppose if you knew the number of paid petitioners, and you knew the total amount paid to them, you could figure out the per petition--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --You could if there was a breakdown that the Secretary did, but they don't.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I thought there was a breakdown.
I asked that question earlier.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I thought it did identify how much was paid to each petition circulator, did it not?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Your Honor, if you ask that question of me--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --I will tell you that the reporting requirement as I understand it is an expenditure, and it's a global expenditure requirement.
