The requirement that was struck down was one which required the distinct reporting of paid circulator's names, addresses, and identifying information.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --The monthly... the monthly one was--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Monthly, exactly right, whereas at the end, the evidence, or the record of the paid circulators is really no different from the record of non, or voluntary circulators.
What happens is, the petitions get turned in.
Those petitions contain the name of the individual who circulated the petition.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: That information is what the Secretary of State uses to first determine--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What is stated about the expenditures, so much... I expended so much for television--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --So much for radio--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --I paid J&J Printing Company $5,000 to print my petition.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Okay.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: This is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You have to show who the money was paid to.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But if it's paid to circulators, don't you have to show the circulator and how much money was paid to each circulator?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: It has been applied as a general reporting requirement, where in 1992 we indicated we paid... I forget, whatever.
I think it was $40,000 to National Voter Outreach for circulation of petitioners without identifying line by line the identity of the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I see.
You pay the national company that hires these circulators, is that it?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So you only have to show what company you paid it to, and these are employees of that company.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: Employees... they... they're paid on a per signature basis under our law in the State of Colorado.
They'd be independent contractors.
The answer to that question is--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: How soon before the election is that final disclosure statement made?
I'm over here.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --Oh, I'm sorry, Justice--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Or is it made after the election?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --The disclosure is made when the petitions are filed with the Secretary of State.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The same day?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: The same day.
There are further disclosures that take place just prior to the election.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But this disclosure, this global disclosure, with the lump sum amount paid for circulation, is filed at the time the petitions are filed?

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: The further disclosures near to the time of the election are not before us.

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: It's near the time of the election, and I--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, but is it... is any issue about those disclosures--

turn.speaker: neil_d_otoole
turn.label: Mr. Neil D. O'Toole
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, there is not.

The only issue in that disclosure is the requirement that while the petition is being circulated, while that contentious issue is before the public, these individuals, who by virtue of the sole fact that they are paid, have to be identified.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Thank you, Mr. O'Toole.
General Gale, you have 1 minute remaining.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: May it please the Court, in clarification to Justice Kennedy's question, the monthly report was stricken by the Tenth Circuit in its entirety.
The final report was stricken to the extent it requires individualized reporting regarding the circulators.
Mr. O'Toole is correct that the final report is submitted at the time that the petition itself is submitted.
There are examples of both of those reports in the joint appendix at pages 41 and 45.
The State has an interest in preventing fraud and misconduct while a petition is being circulated, not simply bribery, but also a husband signing for a wife, something as commonplace as that.
We have the responsibility to the--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, the State doesn't care about this, these things with candidate petitions?

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --Certainly the State does care about these things.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But it doesn't have these requirements.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: It has some of these requirements as--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Not the badge and the paid versus the unpaid and the requirements we're talking about here.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: --That is correct.
It does have the registration requirement, but not the others.
The badge requirement fulfills the function of providing information to the signer.
That person is essentially relying on the circulator as a fiduciary.
The person can... the voter can only sign a petition once.
Once they have signed a petition, they cannot sign that same petition again, and so once they have given over their signature to that person, they have given them a trust responsibility.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, General Norton.

turn.speaker: gale_norton
turn.label: Ms. Gale Norton
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The case is submitted.
